Problem:
Consider the temperature distribution \\(u(x, t)\\) in a flat, thin rod over time \\(t\\), governed by the heat equation \\(\\frac{\\partial u}{\\partial t} = k\\frac{\\partial^2 u}{\\partial x^2}\\), where \\(k\\) is the thermal diffusivity of the rod material. We investigate the impact of a change in boundary conditions defined by the step-function \\(\\phi(x) = T \\) (constant temperature) applied at one end of the rod.

Given the temperature distribution \\(u(x, T)\\) at time \\(T\\), can we precisely determine which boundary conditions were in effect or when they were applied (whether \\(\\phi(x)\\), \\(\\psi(x)\\), or both), by just knowing the temperature distribution at \\(T\\)?
Explanation: Temperature distribution alone at a single time point such as \\(T\\) especially after multiple interventions cannot precisely indicate which conditions were applied or their timing. Various combinations of timing and temperature settings could lead to similar distributions at \\(T\\), making it ambiguous without more detailed time-series data or initial knowledge.
